nodes.text: Ergodicity economics (EE) is pseudoscience because it has not produced falsifiable implications and meets multiple indicators of pseudoscience
EE has produced few testable implications and therefore is not currently falsifiable
EE meets many indicators of pseudoscience such as vague or untestable claims, improper evidence, lack of openness to testing, absence of progress, personalization, and misleading language

Scientific demarcation criteria: Popperian falsifiability and Wikipedia indicators of pseudoscience (vague claims, improper evidence, lack of openness, absence of progress, personalization, misleading language)
Methodological comparison: analyze a standard portfolio optimization model with a risky asset following geometric Brownian motion and a safe asset, investor chooses fixed portfolio fraction theta
Model specification: risky asset price follows geometric Brownian motion with drift mu and volatility sigma, safe return r, wealth evolves lognormally under constant rebalanced portfolio theta
EE prescription for the model: maximize long run geometric average growth rate, yielding optimal portfolio theta = (mu - r) / sigma squared
Expected utility theory (EUT) prescription for the same model with CRRA utility: maximize expected utility gives optimal theta = (mu - r) / (gamma sigma squared)
EE and EUT make identical predictions in this model only when relative risk aversion gamma equals one (log utility)

Although the portfolio model yields a testable implication in principle (parameters mu, r, sigma can be estimated and investor choices compared), EE has not extended to broader settings like multi period consumption and investment, limiting its empirical testability
Publication and review pattern: Peters papers are mainly published in physics journals and only a few are in journals related to economics, indicating limited review by economics experts
Evidence quality issues: EE cites limited experimental evidence (one study) that has been criticized and contains apparent miscitation of prior economic literature
Use of grandiose or vague claims by EE authors, for example asserting resolution of fundamental decision theory and asset pricing without concrete testable applications
Absence of progress: EE primarily revisits older ideas (Kelly criterion and earlier work) and has not produced substantial new developments over many years

Conclusion: Given lack of broad testable implications, limited and contested evidence, restricted disciplinary review, and signs of pseudoscientific practice, EE should be treated with skepticism until it provides falsifiable, empirically testable claims
Scope and author position: analysis focuses on Peters 2019 Nature Physics paper; author is a mathematical economics expert but not an ergodicity economics insider
